unnormalised: **Virtual Classrooms: Are they the future of education in India?**
normalised: **Virtual Classrooms: Are they the future of education in India?**

unnormalised: So, virtual classrooms… what’s the deal, right? I remember back in my day at IIT Delhi, we’d be cramming into lecture halls bigger than my flat in Mumbai now! But times have changed.
normalised: So, virtual classrooms… what's the deal, right? I remember back in my day at I I T Delhi, we'd be cramming into lecture halls bigger than my flat in Mumbai now! But times have changed.

unnormalised: I've been seeing more and more talk about virtual classrooms, especially after the whole lockdown thing. My niece, Priya, is doing her Class 8th online now, and honestly, she seems to be learning way more than I ever did in a physical classroom!
normalised: I've been seeing more and more talk about virtual classrooms, especially after the whole lockdown thing. My niece, Priya, is doing her Class eighth online now, and honestly, she seems to be learning way more than I ever did in a physical classroom!

unnormalised: It's definitely opened up opportunities, especially for folks in smaller towns and villages. Imagine a brilliant teacher in Kerala being able to teach students all the way in Rajasthan. Distance is no longer a huge barrier. Think of the possibilities!
normalised: It's definitely opened up opportunities, especially for folks in smaller towns and villages. Imagine a brilliant teacher in Kerala being able to teach students all the way in Rajasthan. Distance is no longer a huge barrier. Think of the possibilities!

unnormalised: Of course, there are downsides. Screen time is a big concern for parents (and rightly so!). And the lack of face-to-face interaction… that’s a real loss. You can't share biryani with your friends during lunch break in a virtual classroom, can you? Miss those small things!
normalised: Of course, there are downsides. Screen time is a big concern for parents (and rightly so!). And the lack of face-to-face interaction… that's a real loss. You can't share biryani with your friends during lunch break in a virtual classroom, can you? Miss those small things!

unnormalised: But on the whole, I think virtual classrooms are a game-changer. Especially with the growing focus on EdTech in India. What do you guys think? Are virtual classrooms here to stay? What are some creative ways to make online learning more engaging and less...dull? Share your thoughts! Also, anyone tried those virtual reality classroom apps? Are they worth the Rs. 2000 monthly subscription?
